row.Text: This isn't stack overflow. It's a stackexchange, there are exchanges for Bitcoin, Chess, and even videogames.
@PhilipKirkbride that's his point. This isn't SO, and this site shouldn't try to answer dev questions. Those belong on SO.
This is a list of all not declined nominations (not containing "decline"): https://eosio.meta.stackexchange.com/search?q=inquestion%3A15+is%3Aa+-decline

@RobertCartaino your right that the community is in need of moderation if you can't even abide your own code from the theory of moderation you linked above. If my original post was somehow offensive to the community then it was up to the community to not vote me in, not for you to censor it.
Promotional content is removed, not voted on. Please do not continue with this product promotion. It is not appropriate here nor on the site.

@RobertCartaino it's not product promotion it's establishing my credibility as a community supporter. The users deserve to know why they're voting for and I'm allowed to state my case. As I said multiple times I have no financial stake, the app contains neither ads nor methods for monetization, by continuing to censor my posts and remove mention that there's no ads - nor money involved - you're creating a false air of promotion. Your ineptitude and power tripping are the exact reasons I'm self-nominating. You may be director of comms for SX but it doesn't change the fact that you're wrong.

Monetization is not the issue. It's fine when you state that you are a full time developer with the name of the app (which I left as it establishes credibility, like you said), but when it goes on to discuss the benefits of the app and it's free and how to get it with links to download etc, that is beyond what is necessary and appropriate in this context. I should also note that watching someone go straight to the name-calling in comments and flags over a routine good-faith edit is generally a big red flag for us to pass on appointing them as a moderator.
I suppose only moderators can do so as the tags are too similar

I get that you believe your edit was a 'routine good-faith edit' but I suggest you have a look at this wonderful [article](https://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/05/a-theory-of-moderation/). Firstly, no edit is in good faith when altering a candidate's self-representation. You're not editing an answer to a coding question, you're deliberately altering the representation of the candidate to the community. I'm sorry that calling you inept hurt your feelings, I suggest thicker skin if you choose to remain inept in your duties. Inept moderation is a red flag of mine & so is hypocrisy.

@altShiftDev: I jumping in as another community manager from the company to handle flags. To get back to the core issue, I followed the link to your app and it doesn't seem to do anything. (Just a spinner.) So it really doesn't add much to your candidacy. Ultimately the important thing to consider in a moderator is how they interact with the community. That's why the Reddit links haven't been removed.
@JonEricson you probably have javascript disabled but that's beside the point entirely.
it's super important, I just tried to create a question about eosjs and it didn't allow me.
I'm also behind Leo as a moderator, trustworthy guy!
Also behind Leo he has contributed an open-source EOS dapp already https://busy.org/@leordev/monstereos-creating-your-first-monster-in-eos-jungle-testnet
Related https://eosio.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/18/how-can-we-allow-eosjs-tag-but-forbid-eos
Yes but it does not seem to be enabled
I mean: Yes there is code formatting, but no code highlighting (colors) enabled
Thanks a lot for the opportunity! Will give it my best!
Agreed! Thanks for your reviewing activities. If you find some, flag them. The mod team will go through them and remove them or convert them to a comment.
@TeeAttack42 Yes, I flag when appropriate.
Any progress on this? Syntax highlighting would be really useful
I am not sure how to move this forward, I think one of our mods might need to get involved, I've tried pinging them.
I will investigate how to raise this feature-request correctly!
I have written a message to @RobertCartaino (our stackexchange community manger). Will keep you guys updated.

Fantastic question,
I suppose so yes, the stack exchange is EOSIO which represents the software, not the main chain.
Given the different characteristics of each chain, it makes sense to have different tags to filter.
Should we implement this system, however, what's the likelihood of askers knowing to add such a tag?
@JohnWilliamson Developers new to SE may not know. In these cases, if it's obvious to moderators, reviewers or other users, they could create/add tag to the posts as they come across them.
Yeah makes sense! Will wait and see what others think on the idea.

Currently, the incorrect stats with 0 visits/day are even displayed on the right of the main [eosio.stackexchange.com] page, even for users not logged in. It is a bug, sure. Sad that no person able to fix it seems to care, for a month already.
Hi, thanks @animuson and welcome to this site ;)
Thanks! A global lang-cpp tag would be nice!
@TeeAttack42 We set global highlighting to "default" since that works very well for C++, but will not completely break if someone decides to post something else, like XML.
I support this nomination. He is a very active and reviewing member of this community.

It is evidently preferred that users self nominate themselves (1). There does not seem to be an official template for elections ((2) is probably a good start).
It may be too early according to one post which recommends elections take place 6-9 months after the initial launch.
(1)https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/75382/how-can-you-nominate-someone-other-than-yourself-for-being-a-moderator (2)https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1212/community-moderator-election-format-and-design

Generally, we don't run elections until a site is active enough to have an election, meaning it "graduates". For most sites, this is not really time-based but more based on meeting the Area 51 goals, particularly the questions per day. For Beta sites, we usually appoint new moderators if the moderators feel that they can't manage the current work load or if one of the moderators steps down or disappears. In these cases, it's good to know who else we might turn to. That said, we've started running elections on some beta sites, but not on a schedule, based on need.
You can see more about testing beta elections here: https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/314459/experimenting-with-pro-tempore-elections
I pinged someone on the dev team to check on the status of this.
I pinged someone on the dev team to check on the status of this.
Its good for everyone to know as I'm sure some are curious to how supportive block.one is supportive of the developers that post here. Thanks for the dedication btw.

I can't tell who of our community is a member of block.one, but Dan (@Bytemaster). Other participants may be part of the blockproducers or also active in the developer Telegram or GitHub. Also some people (like myself) are just enthusiasts doing this in there spare time.
Yeah I support this too and i support @Nat to have this right as well
That's a solid approach.
Possibly linking the site where/when appropriate, maybe tweeting relevant unanswered questions would draw attention as well.
Thank you to everyone who took part in the election! If you want to contact me for any reason, you can find my contact details on my user profile page :)
Congrats @PhillipHamnett-EOS42 ! Well-deserved!
Thanks @PhilipKirkbride! And congrats @PhillipHamnett-EOS42!
Congratulations @PhillipHamnett-EOS42
